channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: As the Virus Deepens Financial Trouble, Colleges Turn to Layoffs
item.description: The University of Akron this week became one of the first schools in the country to make profound cuts in the number of full-time professors on its staff. Others might have to follow.
item.dc:creator: Daniel McGraw, Shawn Hubler and Dan Levin
item.media:description: The chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, cited uncertain fall enrollment, “particularly with our international student population,” as one of several financial pressures facing the university.

item.title: Mask Rules Expand Across U.S. as Clashes Over the Mandates Intensify
item.description: More retailers and states are instituting mask requirements, but tensions are mounting for people who see the rules as infringements.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh, Manny Fernandez and Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Face masks on display in the window of a custom clothing print shop in Atlanta.

item.title: Seeing ‘Black Lives Matter’ Written in Chalk, One City Declares It a Crime
item.description: In a small Washington town where people of color say they have faced discrimination, activists ran into trouble for drawing “Black Lives Matter” in the streets. Then their white neighbors came to their defense.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabriel Fabian, his girlfriend, Melissa Martinez, and sister Solimar Fabian were invited by their neighbors to draw chalk messages on their driveways in Selah, Wash., after earlier drawings on the street were removed by the city.

item.title: Washington State Beat Back Covid-19. Now It’s Rising Again.
item.description: Washington was the initial epicenter of the nation’s coronavirus outbreak, and an early lockdown helped contain it. Six months later, cases are spiking again, and the future looks uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yakima, Washington’s eighth-most populous county, now has the second-highest number of cases.

item.title: Democratic Officials Tell Members of Congress to Skip the Convention
item.description: The directive ensures that little will happen at the convention in Milwaukee beyond speeches by former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., his vice-presidential nominee and a handful of other top party leaders.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. held a virtual campaign event in March due to coronavirus concerns. The surge in cases have led the Democrats to move their national convention to a mainly online event.

item.title: Reopen Schools? Here’s What You Had to Say
item.description: Parents, teachers and students shared fears and frustrations.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Extending Cruise Ban, C.D.C. Says Ships Helped Spread Coronavirus
item.description: In a scathing order extending the current “no sail” order on U.S. cruise lines, the agency said it spent 38,000 hours managing the outbreaks on ships.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: The Disney Wonder docked in San Diego in March. An outbreak on the ship lasted for weeks.

item.title: Federal Employees Can Express Support for Black Lives Matter, Watchdog Says
item.description: The Office of Special Counsel’s finding came weeks after President Trump called Black Lives Matter a “symbol of hate.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Office of Special Counsel
item.media:description: The office said that using the term Black Lives Matter did not amount to “inherently political activity.”

item.title: How the Twitter Hack Revealed a Risky 2020 Election System
item.description: The breach that targeted Joe Biden, Barack Obama and others served as a warning: Had it happened on Nov. 3, hoping to upend the election, the political fallout could have been quite different.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth and Nick Corasaniti
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Nitashia Johnson for The New York Times
item.media:description: People voted at a library in Dallas this week. The hacking of Twitter on Wednesday revealed another potential avenue for election interference.

item.title: Pompeo Says Human Rights Policy Must Prioritize Property Rights and Religion
item.description: In a speech, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said it was important “for every American, and for every American diplomat,” to recognize how the founders understood “unalienable rights.”
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that “property rights and religious liberty” were two of the most important unalienable rights envisioned by the nation’s founders.

item.title: Who Is Bill Stepien? A Data-Obsessed Campaign Manager for Trump's 2020 Campaign
item.description: Mr. Stepien, a former aide to Chris Christie who has been shadowed by the Bridgegate scandal, brings a data-centric style to the president’s lagging re-election effort.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Amy Newman/The Record, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Bill Stepien is replacing Brad Parscale as President Trump’s campaign manager.

item.title: If Kanye West Is Running for President, So Is Your Mom
item.description: As far as the Federal Election Commission is concerned, Mr. West is an official candidate as of Thursday. Along with 1,144 other people.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: Kanye West, or someone purporting to represent him, has filed the paperwork to run for president.

item.title: Netflix Appoints Ted Sarandos as Co-Chief Executive
item.description: In an earnings report, the company said it had signed up more than 10 million subscribers in the second quarter.
item.dc:creator: Edmund Lee
item.media:description: Ted Sarandos, the content chief at Netflix, will be the company’s new co-chief executive, alongside Reed Hastings.

item.title: Consumers Came Back in June, but for How Long?
item.description: Retail sales increased 7.5 percent, but there are ominous signs that the rebound may fizzle as coronavirus cases rise through much of the country.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari, Michael Corkery and Nelson D. Schwartz
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The way people shop has changed dramatically during the pandemic, with more purchases being done online.

item.title: Barr Urges U.S. Companies to Resist Serving as ‘Pawns’ for China
item.description: The attorney general accused several companies by name of appeasing an authoritarian government to preserve access to a huge consumer market.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr’s speech was the third of four on China by senior Trump administration officials.

item.title: CVS Fined for Prescription Errors and Poor Staffing at Pharmacies
item.description: Regulators faulted four locations in Oklahoma, a rare action that followed complaints at drugstore chains across the country.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler
item.media:description: A pharmacy board in Oklahoma cited safety issues at CVS, the biggest drugstore chain in the United States.

item.title: Trump’s White House Grows Bolder in Flouting Ethical Norms
item.description: The outcry over a photograph of Ivanka Trump with a can of Goya beans reveals how the president and his aides continue to disregard traditional boundaries between the official and the political.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Office of Special Counsel
item.media:description: President Trump and his senior advisers appear far less concerned than their predecessors did about norms and laws governing political activity.

item.title: Supreme Court Allows Restrictions on Voting by Ex-Felons
item.description: The case concerned a Florida state law that limited the sweep of a voter initiative meant to allow former prisoners to vote.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in March.

item.title: A Club of G.O.P. Political Heirs Push Back on Trump
item.description: Mitt Romney, Larry Hogan and Liz Cheney — descendants of sometimes rebellious or resolute Republicans of the past — are dissenting voices on a president who has taken over their party.
item.dc:creator: Mark Leibovich
item.media:description: “I’ve learned that if you don’t follow your conscience, it haunts you for a long, long time,” Senator Mitt Romney said. “At this stage in life, I’m not going to do that anymore.”

item.title: Small Businesses Struggle to Plan for What Comes Next
item.description: For a Baltimore condiment maker with 100 workers, “it’s been a roller coaster” trying to plan for what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Nelson D. Schwartz
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I don’t know what to expect,” said Phil Tulkoff, whose Baltimore condiment company has been in family hands for 90 years.

item.title: Finally, Some Good News (Carved From 90 Pounds of Butter)
item.description: The state fair is canceled because of the pandemic, but the tradition of sculpting a Minnesota dairy princess out of a block of Grade A salted butter will continue, with a few modifications.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Matthew Hintz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Linda Christensen sculpted a butter bust of Rebekka Paskewitz, that year's Princess Kay of the Milky Way, at the 2018 Minnesota State Fair.

item.title: Biden Gets Fund-Raising Help for 2020 Election From Big Democratic Donors
item.description: Mr. Biden is relying on some of his party’s wealthiest donors — and power brokers in Silicon Valley, Hollywood and Wall Street — to cut President Trump’s financial edge, new filings show.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Major donors who once backed other Democratic candidates have rallied behind former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. since he became the party’s presumptive nominee.

item.title: A Big Convention Decision by Democrats, and a Play for White Suburban Voters by Trump
item.description: At a White House event, President Trump mischaracterized a Biden policy proposal and declared, “the suburban destruction will end with us.” A college will require Mike Pence and other attendees to wear masks at a campaign event.

item.title: Fauci Calls White House Criticism ‘Bizarre’
item.description: An under-fire public health expert gently hits back: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: What’s Behind the Shootings?
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Crime scene in Brooklyn where a one year old child was shot and killed on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Shatters Its Record of New Coronavirus Infections as India’s Caseload Hits a Million
item.description: The United States reported more than 75,600 new cases on Thursday, a single-day record. India ranks third in the world in both total cases and new ones, and its rate of new infections is on track to overtake Brazil’s.

item.title: Vacation in the Summer of Covid-19
item.description: Traveling during a pandemic requires lots of research, precision planning and a willingness to play by new and very stringent rules. For these writers, it still felt good to get away.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton, Christopher Solomon, Sheila Marikar and Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:description: A view of the property one writer and his family rented in Searsport, Maine.

item.title: In the Same Towns, Private Schools Are Reopening While Public Schools Are Not
item.description: Private schools have always had more flexibility, and usually more money, but never has that disparity made a bigger difference than now.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller
item.media:credit: Cory Lum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Punahou School in Honolulu will be open full time in the fall. Its donors and alumni have given money to help make that happen.

item.title: Asheville, North Carolina, Approves Reparations for Black Residents
item.description: The measure passed by the City Council of Asheville, N.C., would provide funding to promote homeownership and business opportunities, but stopped short of stipulating direct payments.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Susannah Kay for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asheville, which is in Western North Carolina, apologized for its participation in and sanctioning of slavery, as well as other historical injustices perpetrated against Black people, who make up about 12 percent of the city’s population.
